items.title: South Korea's ex-president jailed for life over martial law attempt
items.standfirst: Yoon Suk Yeol's December 2024 martial law bid fundamentally damaged South Korea's democracy, a judge told the court.
items.content: Yoon Suk Yeol's December 2024 martial law bid fundamentally damaged South Korea's democracy, a judge told the court.

items.title: Former South Korean President Yoon gets life sentence for imposing martial law
items.standfirst: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol was sentenced to life in prison for briefly imposing martial law in a dramatic culmination to the country's biggest political crisis in decades.
items.content: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol was sentenced to life in prison for briefly imposing martial law in a dramatic culmination to the country's biggest political crisis in decades.

items.title: South Korea’s former president Yoon Suk Yeol jailed for life for leading insurrection
items.standfirst: Ex-leader sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labour over failed martial law declaration in 2024A South Korean court has sentenced the former president Yoon Suk Yeol to life imprisonment with labour over his failed martial law declaration in December 2024, finding him guilty of leading an insurrection and making him the first elected head of state in the country’s democratic era to receive the maximum custodial sentence.The Seoul central district court found that Yoon’s declaration of martial law on 3 December 2024 constituted insurrection, carried out with the intent to disrupt the constitutional order. Continue reading...
items.content: Ex-leader sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labour over failed martial law declaration in 2024A South Korean court has sentenced the former president Yoon Suk Yeol to life imprisonment with labour over his failed martial law declaration in December 2024, finding him guilty of leading an insurrection and making him the first elected head of state in the country’s democratic era to receive the maximum custodial sentence.The Seoul central district court found that Yoon’s declaration of martial law on 3 December 2024 constituted insurrection, carried out with the intent to disrupt the constitutional order. Continue reading...

items.title: South Korea sentences ex-president Yoon to life in prison for 2024 insurrection
items.standfirst: A South Korean court on Thursday found ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol guilty of leading an insurrection for his short-lived attempt to impose martial law in December 2024, sentencing the former leader to life imprisonment.
items.content: A South Korean court on Thursday found ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol guilty of leading an insurrection for his short-lived attempt to impose martial law in December 2024, sentencing the former leader to life imprisonment.

items.title: Ex-South Korean president found guilty of insurrection over martial law order

items.content: Yoon Suk Yeol, the impeached president of South Korea, was found guilty of insurrection and sentenced to life in prison on Thursday over his failed attempt to impose martial law on the U.S. ally

items.title: Martial law, protests and a president tried for insurrection: How did South Korea get here?
items.standfirst: A court is due to deliver its verdict in the insurrection trial of Yoon Suk Yeol.
items.content: A court is due to deliver its verdict in the insurrection trial of Yoon Suk Yeol.

items.title: Court to deliver verdict in ousted South Korean president Yoon's insurrection trial
items.standfirst: South Korea's disgraced former president Yoon Suk Yeol could be banished to death row on February 19 when he faces court over his disastrous bid to impose martial law. Seoul's Central District Court will rule on insurrection charges against the 65-year-old, delivering a verdict that will be broadcast live across the nation. FRANCE 24's Sharon Gaffney speaks with Youngmi Kim, Senior Lecturer at the department of Asian Studies at the University of Edinburgh.
items.content: South Korea's disgraced former president Yoon Suk Yeol could be banished to death row on February 19 when he faces court over his disastrous bid to impose martial law. Seoul's Central District Court will rule on insurrection charges against the 65-year-old, delivering a verdict that will be broadcast live across the nation. FRANCE 24's Sharon Gaffney speaks with Youngmi Kim, Senior Lecturer at the department of Asian Studies at the University of Edinburgh.

ai_summary: Yoon Suk Yeol sentenced to life in prison
Found guilty of leading an insurrection
Imposed martial law in December 2024
First elected head of state to receive life sentence
Damaged South Korea's democracy

clusters.title: Ukraine's officials to boycott Paralympics over Russian flag decision

items.title: Ukraine's officials to boycott Paralympics over Russian flag decision
items.standfirst: Ukrainian officials will boycott the Paralympic Winter Games, Kyiv said on Wednesday, after the International Paralympic Committee allowed Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete under their national flag. The EU's sports commissioner Glenn Micallef said he would also skip the opening ceremony. FRANCE 24's Camille Corcoran reports.
items.content: Ukrainian officials will boycott the Paralympic Winter Games, Kyiv said on Wednesday, after the International Paralympic Committee allowed Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete under their national flag. The EU's sports commissioner Glenn Micallef said he would also skip the opening ceremony. FRANCE 24's Camille Corcoran reports.

items.title: Altman and Amodi Refuse to Hold Hands at Modi's AI Summit
items.standfirst: Sam Altman and Dario Amodei, CEOs of rivals OpenAI and Anthropic, refused to hold hands at an AI summit in India. The two tech chiefs were positioned next to each other in a lineup of business and political leaders, and instead stood with their hands in the air and avoided eye contact. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: AI cannot be left to 'whims of a few billionaires', UN chief tells India summit
clusters.neutral_headline: UN Chief Warns On AI Risks

items.title: AI cannot be left to 'whims of a few billionaires', UN chief tells India summit
items.standfirst: UN chief Antonio Guterres warned technology leaders at a global AI summit in India Thursday of the risks of artificial intelligence, saying its future cannot be left to "the whims of a few billionaires". The UN chief called on tech tycoons to support a $3 billion global fund to ensure open access to the fast-advancing technology for all.
items.content: UN chief Antonio Guterres warned technology leaders at a global AI summit in India Thursday of the risks of artificial intelligence, saying its future cannot be left to "the whims of a few billionaires". The UN chief called on tech tycoons to support a $3 billion global fund to ensure open access to the fast-advancing technology for all.

clusters.title: Wave of arrests over killing of French nationalist piles pressure on far left

items.title: Wave of arrests over killing of French nationalist piles pressure on far left
items.standfirst: Eleven people are in detention in connection with the killing of far-right student activist Quentin Deranque.
items.content: Eleven people are in detention in connection with the killing of far-right student activist Quentin Deranque.

items.title: How the killing of a French far-right activist sparked an online manhunt
items.standfirst: The killing of 23-year-old French nationalist Quentin Deranque, on the sidelines of a protest in Lyon, has heightened tensions between far-right and far-left groups ahead of next month's municipal elections. Before any arrests were made, online users claimed to have identified five suspects, leading to the circulation of their personal details. But the internet sleuths got at least one case wrong: a woman identified as Blandine B., who was not even in France on the day of the killing.
items.content: The killing of 23-year-old French nationalist Quentin Deranque, on the sidelines of a protest in Lyon, has heightened tensions between far-right and far-left groups ahead of next month's municipal elections. Before any arrests were made, online users claimed to have identified five suspects, leading to the circulation of their personal details. But the internet sleuths got at least one case wrong: a woman identified as Blandine B., who was not even in France on the day of the killing.

ai_summary: Eleven people detained in connection
Killing of Quentin Deranque sparks arrests
Far-right and far-left groups involved
Tensions high ahead of municipal elections
Online manhunt identified suspects

clusters.title: UK condemns 'appalling' 10-year sentence for British couple held in Iran

items.title: UK condemns 'appalling' 10-year sentence for British couple held in Iran
items.standfirst: A British couple detained in Iran since January 2025 have been sentenced to 10 years in jail for espionage, their family announced on Thursday. The UK government has condemned the prison terms for Lindsay and Craig Foreman as "completely appalling and totally unjustifiable".
items.content: A British couple detained in Iran since January 2025 have been sentenced to 10 years in jail for espionage, their family announced on Thursday. The UK government has condemned the prison terms for Lindsay and Craig Foreman as "completely appalling and totally unjustifiable".

items.title: Jail sentence for British couple in Iran ‘totally unjustifiable’, says foreign secretary
items.standfirst: Yvette Cooper criticises 10-year sentence for couple arrested on around-the-world trip and held on charges of espionageThe 10-year jail sentence handed to a British couple in Iran is “totally unjustifiable”, Yvette Cooper has said.Lindsay and Craig Foreman were arrested in January 2025 while travelling through the country on an around-the-world motorcycle journey and detained on charges of espionage. The couple from East Sussex, who are being held in Tehran’s Evin prison, deny the allegations. Continue reading...
items.content: Yvette Cooper criticises 10-year sentence for couple arrested on around-the-world trip and held on charges of espionageThe 10-year jail sentence handed to a British couple in Iran is “totally unjustifiable”, Yvette Cooper has said.Lindsay and Craig Foreman were arrested in January 2025 while travelling through the country on an around-the-world motorcycle journey and detained on charges of espionage. The couple from East Sussex, who are being held in Tehran’s Evin prison, deny the allegations. Continue reading...

ai_summary: British couple sentenced to 10 years
Found guilty of espionage in Iran
UK government condemns prison terms
Couple denies allegations of espionage
Held in Tehran's Evin prison

clusters.title: Europe will be a 'safe space' for AI innovation, Macron tells India summit
clusters.neutral_headline: Macron Promises Safe Space For AI

items.title: Europe will be a 'safe space' for AI innovation, Macron tells India summit
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron told the AI Impact Summit in New Delhi that the EU would continue to "shape the rules of the game" regarding artificial intelligence in concert with allies, describing Europe as a "safe space" for innovation and investment that would also protect children from digital abuse.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron told the AI Impact Summit in New Delhi that the EU would continue to "shape the rules of the game" regarding artificial intelligence in concert with allies, describing Europe as a "safe space" for innovation and investment that would also protect children from digital abuse.

items.title: Macron Says Social Media Curbs for Youth Will Be G-7 Priority
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron said one of his priorities for the Group of Seven presidency will be protecting children from the harmful effects of social media and artificial intelligence, calling on countries like India to support the measures.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron said one of his priorities for the Group of Seven presidency will be protecting children from the harmful effects of social media and artificial intelligence, calling on countries like India to support the measures.

items.title: France's Macron Vows to Protect Children Against Digital Abuse
items.standfirst: Speaking at the India AI Impact Summit in New Delhi, French President Emmanuel Macron said his country is "embarking on a process to ban social networks for children under 15 years old.” He told the audience that “there is no reason our children should be exposed online to what is legally forbidden in the real world.” (Source: Other)
items.content: Speaking at the India AI Impact Summit in New Delhi, French President Emmanuel Macron said his country is "embarking on a process to ban social networks for children under 15 years old.” He told the audience that “there is no reason our children should be exposed online to what is legally forbidden in the real world.” (Source: Other)

ai_summary: Macron vows to protect children from AI
Europe to be a safe space for innovation
EU to shape rules on artificial intelligence
Social media curbs for youth to be priority
France to ban social networks for under 15s

items.title: NIH's Jay Bhattacharya will also serve as acting CDC director
items.standfirst: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention hasn't had a Senate confirmed director since last summer, and that official was in the job for less than a month.
items.content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention hasn't had a Senate confirmed director since last summer, and that official was in the job for less than a month.

ai_summary: Jay Bhattacharya named acting CDC director
Temporary assignment while searching
Permanent director to be appointed later
Bhattacharya also directs National Institutes
CDC has been without a confirmed director

clusters.title: Benfica midfielder denies racially abusing Vinicius after Real Madrid match halted

items.title: Benfica midfielder denies racially abusing Vinicius after Real Madrid match halted
items.standfirst: Benfica claim there is a "defamation campaign" against Gianluca Prestianni as Uefa launch an investigation into claims he racially abused Real Madrid's Vinicius Jr.
items.content: Benfica claim there is a "defamation campaign" against Gianluca Prestianni as Uefa launch an investigation into claims he racially abused Real Madrid's Vinicius Jr.

items.title: UEFA probing claims Real Madrid forward was racially abused - as Benfica release defiant statement
items.standfirst: UEFA has appointed an ethics and disciplinary inspector after allegations a racist ‌slur was directed at Real Madrid forward Vinicius Junior during last night's Champions League match against Benfica.
items.content: UEFA has appointed an ethics and disciplinary inspector after allegations a racist ‌slur was directed at Real Madrid forward Vinicius Junior during last night's Champions League match against Benfica.

ai_summary: Benfica midfielder Gianluca Prestianni denies racial abuse claims
UEFA launches investigation into alleged racial abuse incident
Real Madrid forward Vinicius Jr was allegedly targeted
Benfica claims defamation campaign against Prestianni
UEFA appoints ethics and disciplinary inspector
